title: Pump Station Micro-Site
subtitle: Drainage + ADA + Utility Tie-ins
description: A small pump station site where you must balance drainage, ADA access, and utility tie-ins under constructability and permitting constraints.

context.jurisdiction: Generic municipality (swap to your local standards later)
context.siteProgram: Small wastewater pump station with fenced yard, wet well, valve vault, generator pad, MCC/control cabinet, and a small parking/turnaround for maintenance truck.
knowns: Parcel is ~120 ft x 90 ft; street frontage on the north.
Existing grade falls ~3% from north to south.
Soils: silty sand; infiltration moderate; groundwater unknown.
Incoming gravity sewer at NE corner; force main exits to west.
Existing 8" water main runs in ROW; power available at NW.
Public access is limited, but ADA route to controls/door is required for staff/contractors.
constraints: Avoid deep excavations near existing utilities in ROW
Maintain access for vacuum truck / maintenance vehicle
Keep O&M safe (drainage away from electrical, ice/ponding awareness)

resources.label: ADA (routes, slopes, ramps)
resources.hint: Cross slope, running slope, landings, curb ramps, gates/hardware. Confirm local amendments.

resources.label: Stormwater manual / BMP selection
resources.hint: Treatment vs flow control; infiltration feasibility; pretreatment; setbacks; overflow routing.

resources.label: Utility separation / cover / crossings
resources.hint: Typical separations, minimum cover, conflicts, corrosion, thrust restraint, access.

resources.label: Pump station yard safety
resources.hint: Drain away from electrical, generators, door thresholds; ice hazards; hose-down considerations.

steps.title: Site Brief
steps.prompt: Review the site program and constraints. First: choose a grading + drainage concept for the fenced yard.

steps.title: Grading + Drainage Concept
steps.prompt: Pick the overall grading/drainage concept for the yard. Goal: keep water away from electrical equipment and provide a safe ADA route.

options.title: Crown the yard; drain to perimeter trench drain at south fence
options.description: Gentle crown near equipment pads; route runoff to trench drain along south fence, then to a small treatment/infiltration feature.
options.rationale: Keeps flow away from pads/door thresholds and offers controlled collection for treatment. Watch trench drain maintenance and freezing.
mentorNotes: Confirm trench drain load rating, cleanouts, maintenance access.
Check slope transitions so ADA cross-slope stays compliant.
Provide overflow path if infiltration underperforms.

options.title: Single-plane slope south (sheet flow) to bioswale outside fence
options.description: Uniform grade sloping south; runoff exits fence via scupper to a bioswale.
options.rationale: Simple and cheap, but sheet flow past gates/equipment can create icing and O&M risk; outfall detailing matters.
mentorNotes: Demonstrate controlled overflow and erosion protection.
Consider winter icing near gate/electrical cabinets.
Confirm discharge is allowed and treatment requirements are met.

options.title: Depress center yard to a catch basin near wet well
options.description: Grade toward a catch basin located near wet well/valve vault for minimal pipe runs.
options.rationale: Low cost and short runs, but concentrates water at sensitive assets. High risk of ponding and O&M problems.
mentorNotes: Avoid ponding near hatches and electrical gear.
Check flood protection/freeboard expectations.
If unavoidable, add redundant overflow and alarm considerations.

steps.title: ADA Route Layout
steps.prompt: Choose how you provide an accessible route from the sidewalk (north frontage) to the control cabinet / building door.

options.title: Direct route through gate; hard surface; manage cross-slope
options.description: Provide a paved/stabilized path from sidewalk to a compliant gate, then to controls with compliant slopes and landings.
options.rationale: Most defensible: clear route, predictable performance, reduces liability. Requires careful grading and gate hardware selection.
mentorNotes: Confirm gate clear width and operable hardware forces.
Keep cross slope ≤ 2% (and confirm local rule).
Provide landings at controls/door and avoid ponding at thresholds.

options.title: No dedicated path; compacted gravel route
options.description: Rely on compacted gravel and yard grading; only provide small landings at controls.
options.rationale: Common cost-saver, but compliance is weak and performance degrades with rutting/ice. Hard to defend in review.
mentorNotes: Expect plan review comments and long-term maintenance issues.
If forced, document maintenance plan and consider a paved strip minimum.

options.title: Short internal ramp over grade break near gate
options.description: Maintain grade at sidewalk; use a short ramp segment inside fence with landings.
options.rationale: Can work well, but ramps demand tight detailing: slopes, landings, edge protection, drainage at ramp toe.
mentorNotes: Avoid concentrating runoff at ramp toe/landing.
Confirm if handrails are triggered by slope/length per jurisdiction.

steps.title: Utility Tie-ins + Conflicts
steps.prompt: Pick a routing approach. Tie in incoming gravity sewer (NE), outgoing force main (west), water service, and electrical. Avoid ROW conflicts and keep access to valves/vaults.

options.title: Shift wet well slightly south to avoid ROW conflicts; keep gravity shallow
options.description: Move wet well/valve vault south; keep gravity inside parcel; reduce ROW utility conflicts.
options.rationale: Avoiding ROW conflicts reduces surprises. A small footprint shift can save major shoring and permit headaches.
mentorNotes: Confirm minimum gravity slope and cover.
Keep clear access around hatches/vault lids.
Coordinate easements if route shifts.

options.title: Wet well near NE corner; accept ROW crossings to minimize runs
options.description: Minimize gravity run length but work tighter to existing ROW utilities.
options.rationale: Efficient on paper, but ROW utility uncertainty drives RFIs, delays, and change orders.
mentorNotes: Call for potholing/SUE early.
Detail shoring near existing utilities and maintain service.

options.title: Force main under ADA route to exit west
options.description: Direct force main alignment under the paved ADA route for shortest length.
options.rationale: Saves pipe but puts future repairs under your primary accessible route. Plan for long-term serviceability.
mentorNotes: Consider sleeves or extra depth to reduce future disruption.
Settlement can break ADA slopes; specify compaction/QA.

steps.title: Stormwater Treatment / Flow Control
steps.prompt: Choose a stormwater strategy. Small impervious area, but public infrastructure often gets high scrutiny.

options.title: Onsite infiltration trench (with pretreatment + overflow)
options.description: Small infiltration trench/drywell with upstream sediment sump pretreatment and a defined overflow path.
options.rationale: Great when soils/setbacks allow; ensure groundwater separation and overflow. Pretreatment is non-negotiable.
mentorNotes: Require infiltration testing or design conservatively.
Provide safe overflow routing for major storms.

options.title: Tightline to street inlet; add water-quality device if allowed
options.description: Pipe runoff to existing street inlet; add hydrodynamic separator or inlet insert if accepted.
options.rationale: Constructable, but depends heavily on jurisdiction acceptance/capacity. May get pushback for new impervious.
mentorNotes: Confirm downstream capacity and treatment requirements.
Get early city buy-in (don’t assume).

options.title: Bioswale outside fence with defined overflow
options.description: Vegetated bioswale outside fence along south line; include overflow back to street system.
options.rationale: Often acceptable and visible; requires O&M agreement and winter performance considerations.
mentorNotes: Confirm setbacks/ownership and who maintains it.
Stabilize outfalls and overflow weirs.

steps.title: Constructability + Access
steps.prompt: Pick how you ensure maintenance vehicle access and constructability while protecting ADA surfaces and utilities.

options.title: Dedicated paved access lane + turning pad; keep utilities out of wheel paths
options.description: Provide access lane/turning pad sized for maintenance vehicle. Route key utilities outside heavy wheel paths where feasible.
options.rationale: Strong O&M outcome; reduces settlement over pipes and preserves ADA surfaces long-term.
mentorNotes: Confirm turning templates and gate geometry.
Coordinate pavement section for loading and trench patches.

options.title: Shared yard surface; crusher-run base; minimal paving
options.description: Minimize pavement; use compacted aggregate and small pads at equipment.
options.rationale: Lower initial cost but higher lifecycle risk: rutting, mud, icing, and ADA degradation.
mentorNotes: If used, define maintenance expectations and mud control at the gate.
At minimum, stabilize the ADA route permanently.

options.title: Pave ADA route only; aggregate access; accept disruption for future repairs
options.description: Prioritize ADA route paving; keep access mostly aggregate; accept higher disruption during repairs.
options.rationale: A middle ground; can work if maintenance frequency is low and soils behave.
mentorNotes: Confirm maintenance vehicle frequency and seasonal conditions.
Define a stable working pad near critical hatches.

steps.title: Design Review Summary
steps.prompt: Here’s how your concept performed. Toggle Mentor Mode to review rationale and build a punchlist of follow-up checks.
